titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert Nathan Papers
titlestmt.author: by Ellen Doon and Clayton McGahee

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 8, 2019 at 04:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection includes drafts of writings, correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, clippings, drawings, diaries, and audio recordings documenting the life and work of the American writer Robert Nathan. Drafts of Nathan's writings make up the bulk of the collection, and include novels, screenplays, short fiction and prose, speeches, and poetry; the writings include story ideas, or "false starts," that Nathan did not publish. Correspondence and other papers document his family relationships, in particular that with his sister Marian Kraus Sandor. Other major correspondents include Stephen Vincent Benét, Herbert Feis, Lawrence Kubie, Dan H. Laurence, and Marjorie Bitker. The collection also documents an exhibition of Nathan's work in the Yale University Library in 1962.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift and Bequest of Robert G. Nathan, 1963-1990; Gift of Anna Lee Nathan, 1986; Gift of Marian Nathan Kraus Sandor, 1970; Gift of John W. Kraus, 2008. Gift of Marjorie M. Bitker, 1982-1985. Gift of Dan H. Laurence, 1966. Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Feis, 1969-1971. Other gifts and purchases as indicated on individual folders.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 80 (audio reels): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Robert Nathan Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert Nathan Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

Large portions of this collection acquired through circa 1985 were processed and cataloged according to the standards at that time, and classed as Za Nathan and Uncat Za Nathan. Material acquired from other sources was classed together with material acquired directly from Robert Nathan and his family; in most cases the provenance is noted within the folders. Material acquired from sources other than the family after circa 1985 was cataloged separately. In 2011, a finding aid was created from the existing folder titles and from catalog cards for the writings in the earlier accessions. For later accessions, material received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization; these acquisitions are listed in this finding aid but have not been merged and organized as a whole with the earlier accessions. Each acquisition (or group of acquisitions) is described separately in the contents list below, identified by the dates of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing between 1964 and 2012. This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

Former call numbers: ZA Nathan, Uncat ZA Nathan, Uncat ZA MS 344, Uncat ZA MS 141, Uncat ZA MS 161, Uncat ZA MS 162, Uncat ZA MS 163, Uncat ZA MS 169, Uncat ZA MS 179, Uncat ZA MS 332, Uncat ZA MS 345, ZA N195 +1, ZA N195 +2, Uncat ZA File 108.

bioghist.head: Nathan, Robert (1894-1985)
bioghist.p: The writer Robert Gruntal Nathan was born on January 2, 1894, in New York City to Harold Nathan, a prominent lawyer, and Sara Gruntal Nathan. He graduated from Philips Exeter Academy in 1912, and attended Harvard, where he edited the The Harvard Monthly . He married in 1915 and left Harvard without a degree in order to support his family. He worked briefly in advertising, but soon became a successful and prolific writer of novels, plays, essays, and poetry. Many of his novels were adapted into films, including The Bishop's Wife (1928) and Portrait of Jennie (1940), and in the 1940s he worked directly as a screenwriter for M-G-M Studios in Hollywood. Nathan was active in the National Institute of Arts and Letters, PEN, and the Academy of American Poets, among other organizations.

After his first marriage to Dorothy Michaels ended in 1922, Nathan married six more times: to Nancy Wilson, 1930-1936; to Lucy Lee Hall Skelding, 1936-1939; to Janet Bingham, 1940; to Clara May Burns, 1951; to Shirley Keeland, 1955-1969; and to the actress Anna Lee, 1970 until his death. He had one child, Joan Nathan Bergstrom, from his first marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes drafts of writings, correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, clippings, drawings, diaries, and audio recordings documenting the life and work of the American writer Robert Nathan. Drafts of Nathan's writings make up the bulk of the collection, and include novels, screenplays, short fiction and prose, speeches, and poetry; the writings include story ideas, or "false starts," that Nathan did not publish. Correspondence and other papers document his family relationships, in particular that with his sister Marian Kraus Sandor. Other major correspondents include Stephen Vincent Benét, Herbert Feis, Lawrence Kubie, Dan H. Laurence, and Marjorie Bitker. The collection also documents an exhibition of Nathan's work in the Yale University Library in 1962.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 4 groupings: Acquisitions 1964-circa 1970, Acquisitions circa 1970-1982, November 1982 Acquisition, and Other Acquisitions.

Material within this collection has been organized roughly by acquisition reflecting the fact that the collection has been acquired in increments over time, and reflecting previous arrangement and description by the library. Researchers should note that material within each acquisition or group of acquisitions overlaps with/or relates to material found in other groups. For instance, correspondence and writings can be found in all groupings. In order to locate all relevant material within this collection, researchers will need to consult each acquisition described in the Collection Contents section. Researchers should also note that similar material can be arranged differently in each acquisition, depending on how the material was organized when it was received by the library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groupings: Writings and Correspondence.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "The Color of Evening", "The Devil with Love", "The Fair", Juliet in Mantua , "The Mallot Diaries", "The Married Man", The Snowflake and the Starfish , So Love Returns , A Star in the Wind , "Digging the Weans", and "The Wilderness Stone".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include Bitter Jewish Poems Rejected from "The Married Man," "Love Sonnet to Sidney Franklin", "Torpedo 8", and "The White Cliffs".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "Belief", "Fourscore", "From a Dying Fire", "Last Song", "Question", "Standing in the Need of Prayer", "To Anne - A Going Away Sonnet", and "To Anne - On April 5, 1981".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "Analist's Song", "A Critic's Garden of Verses", "Epithalamium: for Sandy, a Man of Courage", "Fiftieth Anniversary (Alfred and Blanche Knopf)", "For Lotte Lehmann", "My Turn Will Come", and "There Were Once Two Little Ants".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "Alone", "Harold Adamson", "Psalm 23a (Matilda)", "The Queen Mother's 80th Birthday", "The Swimmer", "To My Wife on Our 10th Anniversary", and "Tom Aston".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "At 85", "The Caged Bird", "Fireside Chat", "Happy Birthday", "I Did Not Know When I Was Old", "In the Firelight", and "June 1979".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "A Memorial Service for Mankind", "The Oak", "The Runner" (also known as "Marathon"), "To Charles at 80" (Charles Bennet), "To My Darling Wife", "To My Valentine", and "Upon Her Shoulders Soft and White".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "Las Vegas - Miracle in the Desert", "The Lockets", "On Dane" - translation postscript to "Digging the Weans," and "The Trumpets".

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Works include "The Absolute Egg", "A Curious Glory", "A Finer Point of Law", "The First Born Jew", "The Hate in Violence", "Letters to the Times", "Listening", and "Terror and Meism".

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 9 subgroupings: May 1990 Acquisition; January 1974 Acquisition; October 1971 Acquisition; December 1965 Acquisition; 1964-1973 Acquisitions; July 1985 Acquisitions; November 1985 Acquisition; Printed Material; October 1985 Acquisition; and April 2008 Acquisition.

This order largely reflects the order in which the earlier acquisitions listed below were formally accessioned following a 1990 bequest from Nathan's estate. This material, acquired between 1964 and 1985, had been shelved apart from the Za Nathan and Uncat Za Nathan groups.
